issue.title: Documentation of instanceOfComponent unclear about array of children
Select component - first draft feedback
issue.body:
[It was decided here](https://github.com/dhis2/notes/issues/58) that we would abandon a native select element in favor of building our own select, compatible with multiple selections and filtering.

[I've made a first draft of the design of this component](https://sketch.cloud/s/DwkDk/a/pJMraZ). I would like to run it past you @dhis2/team-apps so that any required changes can be made before I write the usage docs/build specs. 

## ui-core select

In it's simplest form, a `select` is basically an `input` that opens a `menu`. There are more advanced features, but the composition of the component is based on this idea. Let me run through the features shown in the initial design. Multiple features could be included on one `select`, so you could have a 'Filterable multiselect with progressive loading'.

### Simple single select'

Replaces the native `select` element. Nothing too fancy here. Selecting an item closes the menu by default.

### Filter

The filter is an `input` inside the `menu` that filters the available items, or returns matching items from a server (this depends on how items are fetched). 

### Multiple select

Items in the `menu` display checkboxes that indicate multiple selection is available. Selecting an item does not close the menu by default. Selected items are displayed as removeable `chip` atoms inside the main `input`. The `input` would need to grow in vertical height to accommodate many selections.

### Custom menu items/state

A dev would be able to pass in whatever items they want for selection, it doesn't need to be the basic `ui-core` `menu` with a `menuList`. The example shows some rich content: icons and text. The selected state of menu items could also be customised. My thoughts right now are that the selected state of the `input` would not be able to be customised - an item will always need to pass a string to display in the input.

### Empty state

The component would provide a default empty state along the lines of 'No items found'. This would be customisable, allowing for any content to be shown inside an empty `menu`. 

### Clearable non-required single select

One of the issues with native `select`'s is their inability to deselect an item without the inclusion of a dummy blank item. Ideally we would include a smart control that allows the user to clear the selection. The design includes this 'Clear' control inside the main `input`. I assume this is not possible unless we were making a unique `input` component here (the standard input components we have do not have this control). If this is an issue it can be solved by including a 'clear' control outside of the input. 

### Initial load

Load state if 0 items are prefetched from the server. The menu opens and displays a loading message.

### Progressive load

Load state if items are returned paginated from the server. Scrolling down would trigger the load of `x` more items. How much logic for this do we want to include in the component itself? I do see this being used in many `select`'s across DHIS2, so it seems reasonable to include.

### Inline label

This is useful for toolbars where there is no room for a label. The placeholder text is persisted and the selection is appended.

---

I'm going to get started on the usage docs, all feedback is appreciated. I am particularly interested in any features/functionality that we might want to exclude from this component. I think that all of the included features will be used enough in DHIS2 that they warrant inclusion in this component, but I'm interested to see if there are differing opinions.

comment.body:
The only difference between multi select and single select would be:
1. Displaying the selected option
1. You can select multiple in the multiple one
Other than that, they'd look the same

comment.body:
@cooper-joe looks pretty nice already!

I want to get back to my proposed of not displaying this in a dropdown but make the options always visible (with a max-height?).

The advantages are:
* Multiple selects that are displaying a "loading" state won't be overlapping each other
* You can see the available options while filling in other form inputs
* Consistent style for both single- and multi-selection
If we wanted style consistency with the downdown, the user wouldn't be able to see the selected items when focusing another input
* It works both on desktop and mobile devices
I think this is a biggie, dropdowns are quite a nuisance on mobile devices
_I know we're not supporting mobile screens yet, but I'd us to start thinking that direction.. Mobile devices are the future_

Neutral:
* It'd take more height
We could add a "collapse" button (same style as the `clear` button?)
_We could collapse initially, it'd take one click to open them, just like the dropdown version_

The disadvantages are:
* Many selected items will be difficult to see
We could still do that which chips below/above, it's a bit redundant though

issue.title: Data Engine use cases & API design
issue.body:
This follows from a lively discussion @Mohammer5 and I had at https://github.com/dhis2/app-runtime/pull/19, it's a good read!

**Design Goals** 

A) No application should ever have to make an HTTP request to the DHIS2 server - all interaction with the backend should happen through the Data Engine

B) The consumer of the Data Query APIs should **not need to know or care** about the HTTP requests which might be triggered under the hood.  Any queries might be merged into a single request, or multiple requests, or no request at all if the data exists in the local cache.

I think it's also important to restrict the scope of the Data Engine, at least initially, to only DHIS2 server interactions dealing with the API - no external requests or non-API requests (icons, for instance) should be supported.  The one minor exception to this is legacy `dhis-web-commons/*.action` API-like things.

**Use Cases**
Basically, we need to collect all the possible use cases for the Data Engine so that we can create a well-designed API.  Here are the ones I have so far:

1) Simple one-time query to fetch data (`DataQuery`, often on component mount)
2) Re-fetching of previously fetched data
3) Retrying transient failures like timeouts (should probably happen automatically within the Engine without any consumer interaction)
4) Handling loading states and permanently-failed requests (404 errors)
5) Injecting authentication headers and intercepting authentication and permissions error responses
6) Subscribing to a data stream, automatically polling or listening for changes and notifying the consumer when the data has changed
7) Write and delete operations (`DataMutation`) which turn into API POST/PATCH/DELETE requests (again the HTTP layer is hidden from the consumer)
8) Expression validation - this might be a special case or incorporated into the `DataQuery` implementation, but expression API requests are different than normal API requests in that they're POSTs (and `Content-Type: text/plain`) to support long payloads in the request body.
9) Are there more use cases I'm missing?  Particularly interested in weird / unconventional API patterns people have seen.

comment.body:
Thanks for the exhaustive explanations @varl ! > I usually say that if I have to bet on technology, I'd bet on HTML, CSS, and JS. [...] in the DHIS2 ecosystem that bet has extended to include React. I think it's both important and safe to describe it like this:
Layer 2 React
Layer 1 HTML CSS JS
> > [...] the data engine is easily integrated into redux workflows as well as others. > > An excellent feature to have, though to keep the scope as tight as we can for as long as we can; this is a "yes! ... but not now". So assuming may "layer theory" is correct, we don't need to build a solution that caters inside-of-react only solutions/workflows and can keep in mind that we want to support all kinds of workflows in the future. If we build this service in a way that the data functionality is tightly coupled with the react api, we can only achieve the above with a rewrite, which will get harder the more functionality we add. The code base is still clear and comprehensible, so I think it wouldn't be much work to separate logic / react-logic, we're almost there already. I think it's mainly the `useDataQuery` hook that'd need to be refactored and architecturally separate react from the data engine itself (like creating a `src/connectors` directory) > Redux is not a vital point of our application architecture. It is a great piece of software that we should not hesitate to avoid it if we do not have a need for it. That's true, but many applications are using redux. Changing that would be a very time consuming task. I like the idea behind the data engine and I don't want to miss out on it's features because I'm using redux in an app. I normally don't believe in complete rewrites, the maintenance app is an edge case here (and we're trying to integrate it into the existing one), I think the most pragmatic way is an iterative rewrite. So I'm not trying to say that the data engine should be made to work with redux or that redux is an integral part of our stack, but we have to accept that 1. redux is all over the place and 2. it'd be really good to be able to use the data engine there as well
So we have two possibilities that I can see: 1. Change the data provider so we can easily integrate it into other workflows as well (what we want to do long term anyways), using the least possible amount of effort so we don't introduce breaking changes and from there can continue to build the service I think this is still fairly simple right now, because it involves mainly refactoring the `useDataQuery` hook and the react context stuff (the TS types can stay as they are), it shouldn't be too much work right now. 2. Forge a battle plan for which apps we could/should use the data engine and ignore it in all apps that don't fit that workflow for now; Figure out what the data engine should be capable of and then, at some point, so a rewrite so it can cater to different workflows without hacks/workarounds.
If we decide to go for 2., I think we should talk about the maintenance app refactoring. There are arguments for putting the data engine in there (it'll most likely be one of the most-intense apps in terms of BE-FE communication, so it'll cause the data engine to mature quicker; but it'll slow down the refactoring immensely (new workflow, waiting for features, etc.), and we're already expecting the refactoring to take a lot of time)
Other than that, **I think the workshop would be really useful**. I've "complained" about the lack of documentation already to @amcgee, but understand that the lack of manpower is one of the reasons why it's not there yet (like with any other app that we have). We should def. talk about architectural implementation as a team, but that alone will a be a bigger and isolated topic, so we could have two/three workshops: * Data engine api design * Data engine library architecture * Use cases **Our meeting notes can function as documentation for the service in the future.** What I'm missing specifically is: * How should the service be built architecture wise, is there a plan already or are we doing it on the fly right now; * What are your visions (@amcgee ) of how we address certain problems implementation wise (i. e. how do we forward custom headers, like in the PR that I proposed and rightfully got rejected), do we try to follow a certain pattern (observer pattern?), do we want to use redux internally for storing data (like apollo does, afaik) Things that we have to keep in mind for the battle plan: * Ideally all our apps use the same technologies so devs can work on any app without having to get into the architecture. * What do we want to achieve (repeating @ismay's concern): * Do we want the backend to habe a standardized api? (if so, do we encourage to postpone that/prevent that from happening because we'll move the "standard" to the data engine (unconsciously) instead of pressuring the BE to implement the standardized api)

issue.title: feat: add dense prop to static table
issue.body:
Main goal with this PR is to add the `dense` prop to the cells and rows of the static table (or show what I meant with it at least).

Another small change is that instead of using a `div` to set a `min-height` on the table-cell, this sets a `height` on the table-cell. Which effectively does the same as the cell can still grow larger in height, and it doesn't require an extra element. This way we don't need the global styles.

I've also removed the `min-height` settings from the table row, as they were overriding the table cell heights (when set to `height`). We could put it back in the same manner as the cells (with a `height` instead of `min-height`, and a `dense` prop), but that does mean that setting `dense` on the row will override the cells, which might be confusing.

Btw. I marked my commits as chores since it's a pr for a pr. I'm not sure what the convention is here so let me know if I've done it wrong.

comment.body:
Looks good to me already, just one request:
Could you adjust the 'dense' story so that one column is not dense and contains a button?
Otherwise it wouldn't be clear to me why you'd have to add the dense prop on the cell level instead of row-, tbody or table level

issue.title: Re-export react/prop-types as the default export
issue.body:
To use this library we have to do this:

```js
import propTypes from 'prop-types'
import { instanceOfComponent } from '@dhis2/prop-types'
```

We could do what `fs-extra` does, and re-export the original `fs` module together with the additions it makes, so we could do:

```js
import propTypes, { instanceOfComponent } from '@dhis2/prop-types'
```

Where `propTypes` is the default export from `prop-types` as well.

issue.title: Data Engine use cases & API design
issue.body:
This follows from a lively discussion @Mohammer5 and I had at https://github.com/dhis2/app-runtime/pull/19, it's a good read!

**Design Goals** 

A) No application should ever have to make an HTTP request to the DHIS2 server - all interaction with the backend should happen through the Data Engine

B) The consumer of the Data Query APIs should **not need to know or care** about the HTTP requests which might be triggered under the hood.  Any queries might be merged into a single request, or multiple requests, or no request at all if the data exists in the local cache.

I think it's also important to restrict the scope of the Data Engine, at least initially, to only DHIS2 server interactions dealing with the API - no external requests or non-API requests (icons, for instance) should be supported.  The one minor exception to this is legacy `dhis-web-commons/*.action` API-like things.

**Use Cases**
Basically, we need to collect all the possible use cases for the Data Engine so that we can create a well-designed API.  Here are the ones I have so far:

1) Simple one-time query to fetch data (`DataQuery`, often on component mount)
2) Re-fetching of previously fetched data
3) Retrying transient failures like timeouts (should probably happen automatically within the Engine without any consumer interaction)
4) Handling loading states and permanently-failed requests (404 errors)
5) Injecting authentication headers and intercepting authentication and permissions error responses
6) Subscribing to a data stream, automatically polling or listening for changes and notifying the consumer when the data has changed
7) Write and delete operations (`DataMutation`) which turn into API POST/PATCH/DELETE requests (again the HTTP layer is hidden from the consumer)
8) Expression validation - this might be a special case or incorporated into the `DataQuery` implementation, but expression API requests are different than normal API requests in that they're POSTs (and `Content-Type: text/plain`) to support long payloads in the request body.
9) Are there more use cases I'm missing?  Particularly interested in weird / unconventional API patterns people have seen.

comment.body:
### Preface

This issue has split in multiple directions:
1. Use cases
1. Api of the data engine
1. Architecture of the data engine
(not how it's working internally but how we compose different goals in one library)
1. Area of application

This comment is not about what the data engine could/should do in terms of complexity or which domains it should handle nor is it about the architecture.
**I'd like to address the lib's area of application.**

So I won't lay out general use cases, because it's not what I'll like to talk about in the following comment.
I'll try to do that in other comments, which will take more time I think.

We could also think about splitting this issue into 4 issues, so we end up with:
1. Data engine use cases
1. Data engine api design
1. Data engine library architecture
1. Data engine area of application

<hr />

### Area of application

> > I simply don't see the advantage to put this into the components, maybe you can shed some light on this?

> A strong reason is to support "pure react" applications
> [...]
> we're building it for the larger community so the goal [...] is to make simple things simple [...] also hard things possible and [...] standardize/centralize our more advanced applications.

Our community is not purely react based. WHO has used angular (did we inherit them all?), I don't know what team android uses (react native or java?), I'm sure there are other techs as well.
But even if our community was purely react based, by offering an inside-react-only solution seems counterproductive to me.

Our applications follow redux standards or are trying to go that direction, so in order to keep things simple, we need a solution that works well in both pure react apps as well as redux apps.
To me this does not mean that a pure react implementation works together with redux apps, but that the data engine is easily integrated into redux workflows as well as others.

**And ideal solution would**
* **work in all environments**
* **keeping "simple things simple" & "hard things possible"**
* **keeps everyting being centralized.**
* **is implementation-ideologically language- & platform-agnostic**

<hr />

### Subscription based functionality & area of application connectors

An internal subscription mechanism (not talking about rxjs!), maybe similar to what final-form does, is very performant, can be controlled granularly, is not opinionated and can easily be ported to different contexts (writing a `useDataQuery` hooks would be quite "simple", and so would be integrating it with redux, which is subscription based as well (probably not as trivial as the hook, but still fairly simple))

It's an approach / design pattern / strategy that can be adopted by other languages as well and serves our greater plan to eventually render apps in one top-level app, without having to transform all of them to use the data engine in the react tree.

> A second important reason is re-usability and context isolation [...]
> a smart component in a shared library shouldn't need to use redux for data fetching.

I'm not arguing in favor of changing the direction to redux instead of react, I'm for pulling out the logic so we have an environment-independent solution that still meets the criteria you've mentioned (simplicity, being able to tackle all sorts of problems and being centralized)

<hr />

### Conclusion

I think the ideal scenario for me in this case is:
Rewrite the data engine so it's not opinionated about the area of application and provide the `useDataQuery` hook, so it's not a breaking change.

Then we (doesn't need to be you) can add actionCreators / reducers (reducerCreators?) so we'll end up with the same functionality and simplicity of integrating the data engine.

It could even be (but doesn't necessarily need to be) it's own library, so the data engine doesn't know about it and will never tend to lean towards a certain area of application.

comment.body:
@hendrik I think you'd have the same query in all these components as they'd be cached anyways, but it still seems a bit odd this way

@amcgee I was trying to find good examples, but it's really hard at this stage, because don't use the data engine anywhere yet on a larger scale. So we're mainly talking about theoretical issues and from developer experience.

issue.title: Handling different viewport sizes
issue.body:
I have silently added breakpoints to my table proposal in https://github.com/dhis2/ui-core/pull/304,
which has triggered a discussion about if/how we should handle responsive styles.

So I think it's time we start talking about what we want to do properly (let's see if our component & design system is mature enough so we can come to a conclusion here)

## Requirements

There are some requirements that we'll have to take care of:

### Different layouts of components can be needed regardless of viewport dimensions
This is most likely the case for components rendered in resizable containers, here's what @cooper-joe said:

> I think the 'responsive' styles are actually more useful for embedded tables than mobile, at least for the time being. Tables are often embedded in dashboard items/tracker widgets. These widgets are user re-sizable.

_**This can't be solved with breakpoints!**_

### Different component-layouts based on content/page-layout
Components will most likely render differently when placed in a sidebar instead of the main content area

_**This can't be solved with breakpoints!**_

### Component-layouts that change for different viewport sizes
Many component layout won't make much sense on phones and tablets (desktop view of the org unit tree or group editor for example). These changes can't be determined by the page's layout area they're placed in

_**This can be solved with breakpoints only!**_

### Custom breakpoints defined by apps
Some apps will have content that's unique for those apps. 

_**This will conflict with hard-coded breakpoints in out component libraries!**_

## Proposal

So in order to get a grip on this problem, I'll lay out my preferred solution to this.
It's won't cover all possible cases, so obviously there will be some limitations.

### Final goal

What I'd like to end up with is 

* having mature component libraries that build on `ui-core`, like `ui-widgets`. Once we're there, apps won't use `ui-core` anymore except for rare cases.
* having layout components for the page layout that cover our common layouts. Ideally we base all our apps on these layouts, trying to reduce custom implementations to a minimum
* The mature component's layout can be changed in two ways:
  1. By explicitly defining the layout (with react props), so re-sizable containers have full control over their content's behavior
  2. By defining the component's layout based on which page layout area they're in
* Component's behavior that's based on the page layout can be switched off via react props (this should enable the app to define custom styles

#### Custom layouts / responsive styles

I'd like to reduce custom styles to a minimum for some reasons and base most of the behavior on the page's layout:

1. It'll reduce the amount breaking changes when working on components libraries
2. It'll enable us to change layout behavior without having to touch apps
3. The layout container that defines the behavior can be replaced with a custom container while keeping the area components from `ui-core`, so if there's really a need for something custom it still can be done
4. Components that are placed in a page layout area should try to avoid changing as much as possible, just adjusting in a fluid fashion to width changes (but of course for some components that won't be possible)

#### Drawbacks

If we define behavior in our component libraries, we'll end up with some fixed (pixel based) values eventually, so we will have trouble with custom breakpoints, so this is something we'd need to avoid.
With a proper/mature design system this should be do-able and even preferable

If we don't define behavior in our component libraries, we'll end up with different responsive styles in our apps and we'll have to determine component behavior with javascript because we can't use breakpoints in our component libraries.

comment.body:
> I'm not 100% sure about this, but I think we have some formally supported measure of minimum screen width.

Yes we currently don't support smaller screens, but looking at the development of devices, there's a trend towards small, mobile devices is Asia (and I assume it's similar in Africa) and I think we should think a bit more progressively here

comment.body:
@cooper-joe could you also add line-height values to the specs? This will def. help in the future to use the correct values.
Btw, it's generally a bad idea to use
(in-depth info: https://iamvdo.me/en/blog/css-font-metrics-line-height-and-vertical-align)

* font-size to determine an elements height
font-size does not determine the height of an element, the font itself does (if there's no explicit line-height value).

* use the same value for both font-size and line-height
When using the same line-height as font-size, you might end up with touching characters.
We can solve this with padding of course, but as long as we have control over the font, we can also do this with line-height (which we should use anyways) without having to use padding

issue.title: Logging
issue.body:
I'm wondering if there is a recommended approach to logging to the console from our apps. I've seen regular, unconditional, `console.log()` statements being used for errors and the like. And I think I've seen a couple of other approaches as well.

Personally I don't like the logging during tests that much as I find it a bit noisy. In general I think I would prefer it if the logging was toggle-able. So:

1. I was wondering if there is already an agreed upon way to handle logging in our apps.
2. With regards to making logging toggleable, something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/debug has always worked well for me. It'll allow us to toggle logging for any module that implements it, not just the one you're working on currently, with environment vars.

I'm wondering what everyone thinks of this / prefers, etc.

comment.body:
@HendrikThePendric I think that'd be true if we were only talking about an app itself or a library itself.

To me, the two biggest advantage are:

1. I can enable to debug modules of libraries
like ui-core, ui-widgets, ui-forms, possibly app-shell and app-runtime as well.
If we have documented our libs' api and responses properly, this shouldn't be necessary.

2. I can watch complex processes in a linear way (let's say you'd have to debug the maintenance app, it's ridiculously difficult to know what's happening, and where).

<hr />

We could also do this: Use `ulog.info` only, and disallow `log` and `debug`.

`info` should then mainly display the steps of the processes defined by a feature (spec)
`log` and `debug` would be used for developing and should be stripped before a PR is approved

2. With regards to making logging toggleable, something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/debug has always worked well for me. It'll allow us to toggle logging for any module that implements it, not just the one you're working on currently, with environment vars.

I'm wondering what everyone thinks of this / prefers, etc.

comment.body:
> How do we prevent too many log statements from gradually being introduced into our codebases?

I think this can only be done with experience, we could start with one app (I think the new maintenance is a app to start with) and see how it feels, if we have the feeling of having too many or to few info/log/debug statements)

> My main concern is that I am not convinced that anyone is ever able to distinguish between log statements that are relevant now, and ones that are going to remain relevant indefinitely?
> [...]
> It's quite likely that when new features are introduced they are initially a bit unstable and bugs will pop up. It may now seem justified to put some log statements in and keep them in indefinitely.

I think we have to use the correct log leves, then this should be a lot clearer.
`info` should only be used for information that's going to be relevant later
`debug` should be used for debugging purposes, also during development

> How to decide what to log (and what not to log)?

This is what has worked best for me:

> * `info` for general process steps
> * `log` for detailed steps (think of verbose)
> * `debug` for logging more than just messages, like objects, responses, etc.

I guess the `info` statements could/should stay indefinitely and will most likely be removed when code changes.

> How manage the amount of log statements in a codebase?

Trial and error and collaboration (PRs), there's no automated way to detect the right amount of log statements

> How would a "cleanup" be triggered?

I think cleanup is a part of refactoring. We now have the possibility to work on such things before an issue is done (#55), so whenever you encounter too many log statements which are outside of the frame of your issue, you can create another small branch/PR, that addresses exactly this

> Or alternatively, I guess we could also collectively decide that having lots of log statements in our codebase is not a bad thing. You'd have to convince me on this first ;-)

If we follow proper architecture patterns and we lean towards the "1 function 1 task/purpose" strategy (which I think we already do and is normal in FP), we might end up with lots of info/log/debug statements, but they're only few when you look at a file (but there'd be many files with logging).

We'd also have to follow some common logging patterns:
1. Write full sentences that explain the context ("No data" is not helpful at all)
1. Don't just repeat declarative code (like logging the function's name that's being called, it still lacks context)

I'd propose we try it out and see if it actually helps, because the experience I had last weekend was:
I understand function internals (with `log` statements) without having to read the imperative code bits until I need to know them to that level of detail.

issue.title: Team-apps JIRA workflow
issue.body:
There's no documentation of how our workflow works in-detail, so I'd like to sum up what I've understood so far to see whether I'm right or not. **Eventually the result of this discussion should turn into docs somewhere prominent and easily accessible for team-app devs!**

### 1. Todo

* Everything in here is prioritized and ready to be picked up.
* Normally it should not have an asignee
* It can have an assignee when
  * The issue came back from testing
  * It's clear who'll do that issue anyways

There's nothing to be done here by devs other than picking an issue when looking for work.
When picking an issue, the dev should
1. assign it to him-/herself
2. move it to "In progress"

### 2. In progress

* Issues in this column should
  * be actively worked on
  * or on hold because it's blocked by sth else after having started to work on it
    (This means that blocked issues that haven't been worked on yet should be in "Todo")

Once a developer is done working on an issue and has created a PR, **before backporting, adding JIRA test issues and updating the docs**, the issue is moved to "In review" and assigned to another team-apps developer who should review the issue

### 3. In review

* Issues in this column should at least have a PR attached to them
* The issue will bounce back and forth between the developer and reviewer whenever something is missing until all requirements are fulfilled (JIRA test issue, updated docs, backporting), always including a comment by the reviewer what is missing

For some reasons issues should move to "In review" before adding tests and docs:
1. Docs would be "live" before the issue has been merged
2. Implementation might change based on the result of the review which would require a change of the previously merged doc changes
3. Implementation might change based on the result of the review which would require a change of the previously added JIRA test issue

The reviewer should **always** leave a comment on the issue when assigning it back to the developer to make it clear in the issue's history what has happened. This could be "Code works, please update docs, add test cases and backport to specified target versions".
**Finally, after everything has been added & has been checked by the reviewer, the reviewer moved to issue to "testing", as assigning it back to the developer would be an unnecessary step**

comment.body:
> So I tend to start looking into a new issue once an issue I'm working on is set to testing.

@birk To give you a bit of context here, I was talking to @varl yesterday, saying that I feel a bit frustrated with having too many context switches, hence we were talking about what I/we could do to reduce exhaustive context switches

To me, this doesn't start with testing. I often found myself starting a new topic when requesting the review for the main PR, delaying backports to when the PR has been accepted, because some have a lot of changes and it's almost guaranteed that I have to adjust things. In the worst cases, this can take weeks.

I don't think working on two issues (one in "In progress" and one in "In review") is too much of context switching normally. It can happen though that you end up with two or three issues in "In review" and one in "In progress", and whenever something changes, some of the questions I ask myself when I get a notification that something has been updated are:

* Is it a critical bug that has much higher priority so I should stop working on what I'm doing now
* Do I have enough time to finish both what I'm working on now and the updated issue so they make it into the next minor release
* Is someone waiting for my PR to be merged / backported, do I silently block someone else work or should I respond to the update simply because it's quite a cognitive overhead to read into the code changes and I don't want that person to wait too long for my response, otherwise they'd have to read all that again
* etc.

Then I'm already trying to think about both issues, that might be a personal issue which you guys don't have, or maybe you do. So of course it's up to us, how many issues we can handle once they're in "In review", but with what @varl has added, we now have to possibility to not start a new JIRA issue if we feel it'd interrupt our workflow too much and we use the time holes instead to either do some refactoring, increase documentation/test coverage or work on one of our libraries because the switch doesn't trigger as many administrative questions)

> > Write documentation for the surrounding context or the feature
> 
> This is a requirement to pass the review, so it should be done before a review is requested.

The surrounding context doesn't need to be the context of the feature. When you realize that there's documentation missing that could've helped you working on the issue but has nothing to do with the issue itself, you're not required to document that part of the app

issue.title: Logging
issue.body:
I'm wondering if there is a recommended approach to logging to the console from our apps. I've seen regular, unconditional, `console.log()` statements being used for errors and the like. And I think I've seen a couple of other approaches as well.

Personally I don't like the logging during tests that much as I find it a bit noisy. In general I think I would prefer it if the logging was toggle-able. So:

1. I was wondering if there is already an agreed upon way to handle logging in our apps.
2. With regards to making logging toggleable, something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/debug has always worked well for me. It'll allow us to toggle logging for any module that implements it, not just the one you're working on currently, with environment vars.

I'm wondering what everyone thinks of this / prefers, etc.

comment.body:
> With debugging I'm usually already focusing on a certain area and have an idea of what I'm looking for. Any extra messages are annoying to me in that case. I just want to see the logs I'm interested in.

This is totally possible with `ulog` with `DEBUG=dhis2:lib:ui-widget:header-bar:* LOG=0` (or the localStorage variant)

ulog will log everything from error level to debug level for the specified namespace, all other namespaces depend on the log level.

> Switch on log messages per area easily (in dev and production)

I'm not sure what we can do to turn on `ulog`'s logs in production, but I haven't looked for it either, but I'm sure there is a way if we want to?

> Maybe we should see if we can converge on the intended goals first? I'm not sure if we're all aiming for the same thing? If I reformulate what I said earlier I think the clearest I can state what my aim was is:
> 
> * Switch on log messages per area easily (in dev and production)
> * No console.logging by default in production
> * Uniform approach to logging debug messages

I agree with the last two points, I don't agree with the first one:
1. You can spin up your dev env on master with the appropriate play/debug environment and you'll have the same log/debug messages (and a direct link to the source file as the code is not uglified)
2. For debugging actual production environment (the ones with actual people's data), we should aim for this: https://jira.dhis2.org/browse/DHIS2-3481 (storing error messages and opt-in to sending them to us, so we know what's happening in the wild)

I've talked to @varl about No 2 today and we both feel the we need to try to get this going

issue.title: Rework text input (replace outlined style)
issue.body:
I made a mistake with the input fields. I was writing the documentation for filled/outlined styles and I realised I couldn’t really justify where one would be used over the other. I made the mistake of taking this from Material Design without doing due dilligence. 

To rectify this, I would like to replace the 'outlined' style with a regular, traditional, split label+input style. The 'filled' style can remain unchanged.

To be clear, the input types we would then have:
- filled
- traditional split (separate? Lacking a good name)

Apologies that this will undo some work already done to a high standard. I spoke to @varl and he thought we might be able to make these changes to the outlined style without making breaking changes. I think it may be possible, all the states remain the same functionally (error, disabled, dense etc.), it is visually that there are big changes. Ideally I would like to make this change soon, before apps start using the outlined style extensively.

Please grab me on slack to discuss if needed. Here are the specs: https://sketch.cloud/s/DwkDk/a/jO5k5b



CSS for the input box-shadow, for easy copy&paste:
```css
box-shadow: inset 0 0 0 1px rgba(102,113,123,0.25), inset 0 1px 2px 0 rgba(102,113,123,0.21);
```

issue.title: Data Engine use cases & API design
issue.body:
This follows from a lively discussion @Mohammer5 and I had at https://github.com/dhis2/app-runtime/pull/19, it's a good read!

**Design Goals** 

A) No application should ever have to make an HTTP request to the DHIS2 server - all interaction with the backend should happen through the Data Engine

B) The consumer of the Data Query APIs should **not need to know or care** about the HTTP requests which might be triggered under the hood.  Any queries might be merged into a single request, or multiple requests, or no request at all if the data exists in the local cache.

I think it's also important to restrict the scope of the Data Engine, at least initially, to only DHIS2 server interactions dealing with the API - no external requests or non-API requests (icons, for instance) should be supported.  The one minor exception to this is legacy `dhis-web-commons/*.action` API-like things.

**Use Cases**
Basically, we need to collect all the possible use cases for the Data Engine so that we can create a well-designed API.  Here are the ones I have so far:

1) Simple one-time query to fetch data (`DataQuery`, often on component mount)
2) Re-fetching of previously fetched data
3) Retrying transient failures like timeouts (should probably happen automatically within the Engine without any consumer interaction)
4) Handling loading states and permanently-failed requests (404 errors)
5) Injecting authentication headers and intercepting authentication and permissions error responses
6) Subscribing to a data stream, automatically polling or listening for changes and notifying the consumer when the data has changed
7) Write and delete operations (`DataMutation`) which turn into API POST/PATCH/DELETE requests (again the HTTP layer is hidden from the consumer)
8) Expression validation - this might be a special case or incorporated into the `DataQuery` implementation, but expression API requests are different than normal API requests in that they're POSTs (and `Content-Type: text/plain`) to support long payloads in the request body.
9) Are there more use cases I'm missing?  Particularly interested in weird / unconventional API patterns people have seen.

comment.body:
After using the data engine in the new maintenance app, I have a few concerns:

### "Slow" development due to the lack of developers

Currently it's only @amcgee working on the library, I've prepared two PRs which where (for good reasons) rejected. But it also means that when there's a demand for features/bug fixes, there's only a limited set of people who can actually work on this

### data 'retrieval' logic in components

This has bugged me lately when working on components that should only be shown when the user has certain privileges/authorities. Of course I can get it to work, but it feels quirky (especially when having a dynamic set of requests.

But it also feels the same like in the old OOP days where logic and state was spread through the application and it was very hard to find out where stuff is, especially when shared between autonomous components.

### It won't work out of the box with libraries that have been written for redux

Best example is what I've mentioned before on this issue: react-router with connected-react-router, history, location, combining selectors, etc.

>  I'd prefer something low-level and general like that

I'm not arguing about the functionality per se, just think that 
* having it in the components is the wrong place,
* I'd prefer it this was composable with industry standards like redux (like what apollo offers)
* and what @ismay said in his last comment.

issue.body:
I'm wondering if there is a recommended approach to logging to the console from our apps. I've seen regular, unconditional, `console.log()` statements being used for errors and the like. And I think I've seen a couple of other approaches as well.

Personally I don't like the logging during tests that much as I find it a bit noisy. In general I think I would prefer it if the logging was toggle-able. So:

comment.body:
I've been playing around with `debug`, `ulog` and combining them, and I think `ulog` is the lib to go here.

<hr />

It will def. clutter code, but I think we can regard it as code comments which will be printed on the console at runtime as well.

They actually can even help reading through code because you know what's happening without having to read every single line of code.

What has worked best for me last weekend was:
1. `ulog.info` for general process steps
1. `ulog.log` for detailed steps (think of `verbose`)
1. `ulog.debug` for logging more than just messages, like objects, responses, etc.
The name is a bit off, maybe `stories` suits this one better?

issue.title: Logging
issue.body:
I'm wondering if there is a recommended approach to logging to the console from our apps. I've seen regular, unconditional, `console.log()` statements being used for errors and the like. And I think I've seen a couple of other approaches as well.

Personally I don't like the logging during tests that much as I find it a bit noisy. In general I think I would prefer it if the logging was toggle-able. So:

1. I was wondering if there is already an agreed upon way to handle logging in our apps.
2. With regards to making logging toggleable, something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/debug has always worked well for me. It'll allow us to toggle logging for any module that implements it, not just the one you're working on currently, with environment vars.

I'm wondering what everyone thinks of this / prefers, etc.

comment.body:
I've played a bit around with `ulog` just now, here's what I can say:

* It supports both namespaces and log level (which is quite nice)
This is something we were missing with `debug`, at least in terms of out of the box functionality
* It supports multiple arguments to their logging functions (just like console.log)
This is different with `debug`, where you'd have to use `%[X]`, I like the `ulog` way more
* It does not print the namespace coloured
This is an advantage of debug, because it increases readability quite a bit
* It does not print the time between following logging functions if they're from the same namespace
This doesn't really matter to us anyways I think

It's quite easy to create a wrapper for `debug` to have the log level functionality as well, but it requires a wrapper while it's quite hard to get the coloured outputs of `debug` in `ulog`.
To me it breaks down to:

* if we're fine with a wrapper (lib or runtime service?), I'd go for `debug`
* if we want to use only the out of the box functionality of those libs, I'd favor `ulog`

issue.title: Multi select component for ui-core
issue.body:
Our current `<SelectField>` component does not yet support the `multiple` attribute. We had a talk about how to build it on slack (see [here](https://dhis2.slack.com/archives/CBM8LNEQM/p1564487918000500))

## Background info

* The native multi-select is not that accessible if you don't know how it works, as it needs a keypress to make multiple selections: https://jsfiddle.net/w8qznyc1
* A library that handles multi selects differently than native: https://harvesthq.github.io/chosen (not usable by us though, but a nice example)
* The material-ui multi select: https://material-ui.com/components/selects/#multiple-select
* And over there 👉, on the side, the Github multiselect (see assignees, labels)

In the talk, Joe asked:

> I think that the decision needs to be made: are we staying strict native and adapting DHIS2 UI’s to that, or are we building something custom to DHIS2 needs? Once that decision is made I can work on a proper design spec in collab with you guys

## Proposal

Personally I think that having the SelectField stay close to a native SelectField would be nice. It would keep the code and the component simple. My proposal would be this:

1. Allow a `multiple` attribute on our SelectField. That would then functionally make it work like the [material-ui multi-select](https://material-ui.com/components/selects/#multiple-select), which is closest to our current select-field, and works well I think (though an `X` on a chip to remove it might be nice).
2. For more complicated situations, like when you want filtering, searching, paging, I'd propose a different component, say a `Combobox`. Which is more dynamic, and has a searchfield, etc.

Obviously devs would have to be sensible and not use a SelectField with `multiple` for rendering 10000 items. That's where they'd need to use the ComboBox.

Let me know what you think if you want to partake in the amazing journey of the 📯Dhis2 Multiselect! 📯

issue.title: Logging
issue.body:
I'm wondering if there is a recommended approach to logging to the console from our apps. I've seen regular, unconditional, `console.log()` statements being used for errors and the like. And I think I've seen a couple of other approaches as well.

Personally I don't like the logging during tests that much as I find it a bit noisy. In general I think I would prefer it if the logging was toggle-able. So:

1. I was wondering if there is already an agreed upon way to handle logging in our apps.
2. With regards to making logging toggleable, something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/debug has always worked well for me. It'll allow us to toggle logging for any module that implements it, not just the one you're working on currently, with environment vars.

I'm wondering what everyone thinks of this / prefers, etc.

comment.body:
I think @varl has a fair point about code getting cluttered with debug statements, if we're trying to have a sophisticated approach.

So maybe a step back here:
* Let's not put debug statements in our apps
* We could still do it for libraries, because these are harder to debug in app context
The component libs will most likely also need fewer debug statements as they contain little to no business logic (data provider might be different here, but I think that's a data provider specific issue then)

I've talked about this with @ismay a bit more in depth on slack yesterday, and we arrived at a conclusion that I have been a bit mistaken about the purpose of `debug`:
I wanted to use it for logging as well while the purpose is debugging only

`debug` offers a way to override the logging function:
https://github.com/visionmedia/debug#output-streams

With this, we'll have the different log levels at hand:

```js
import Debug from 'debug'

const createDebug = () => Debug('dhis2')

const debug = createDebug()
debug.log = console.log.bind(console)

const logInfo = createDebug()
info.log = console.info.bind(console)

const logWarning = createDebug()
info.log = console.warn.bind(console)

const logError = createDebug()
info.log = console.error.bind(console)

export { debug, logInfo, logWarning, logError }
```

Maybe we can utilize this somehow?
